Hi Wheelers & Froggy. Thank you for your reply. I will answer both questions.

Wheeler - The reason why it is difficult to contact people via cell phones is The Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA) (47 U.S.C. 227 , 47 CFR 64.1200) prohibits the use of an “automatic telephone dialing system” to contact “any telephone number assigned to a cellular telephone service” without “express prior consent” from the party being called. Based upon this federal law, the only way you can legally poll someone with a cell phone is if they have provided prior consent via the Do Not Call registry system. It is widely estimated that less than 30% of Americans with cell phones only have given their consent to be contacted for polling and other solicitations via their cell phones. Consent is not granted when one opens a cell phone account. The owner has to initiate the consent.

Froggy - We use extensive election statistical that is complied by municipal and county clerks. the Qualified voter file contains demographic stats on each registered voter. We work with the clerks to compile their individual statistics over a number of elections that fit our model profile. For the Michigan 2012 general election, we are using 15 elections in our model. Using the 2008 exit polls to project the 2012 electoral universe is extremely limited for construct a detailed model for state turnout. In Michigan, African American seniors ages 66 and older and middle aged voters get missed in exit polling samples.

It's refreshing to see a piece from someone who has taken more then a couple days to learn about Mormonism before writing, and also of course the headline is ingratiating, especially compared to many that have come out in the past. That said, this article unfortunately and seriously misrepresents Mormon belief. 1500 characters isn't enough to explain, but here are a few of the more important clarifications:

"The Mormon God is somewhat hedged in by the universe, and not master of it."- Very untrue. Mormons know God is omnipotent, and is absolutely master of the universe. He is not separate from or external to the universe/multiverse, as some conceive Him to be, but he is definitely not "hedged in" by it either.

"through heroic effort and striving, God was a man who became exalted" A bit closer; it is true that Smith knew God as a being who had himself undergone progression, but not really by "effort and striving"; Mormons don't think you simply try hard enough and "poof" become God, rather theoretical and esoteric concept of deification is an unfathomable and eternal process over aeons, not self-enabled either. It should also be emphasized that the everyday Mormon doesn't preoccupy themselves with trying to conceive of God's every characteristic, or dream of becoming some celebrity Zeus themselves. Eternal progression is a gift of God and a natural process, not something earned or pretended upon. Does a morula become an adult through "effort and striving?"

This is Psalm 82, in the King James version 82:1 "God (elohim) standeth in the congregation of the mighty; he judgeth among the gods (elohim)" and the later 82:6 "you are gods (elohim) all of you." In the first passage the first use of "Elohim" is singular, a standard use of "Elohim" to stand in for the name of g-d, but the second is plural; other translations, and most interpretations, take the second as "powers" or "angels" rather than "gods" along with 82:6. Genesis 1:26 use of the plural ("let us make man") and 11:7 ("come let us go down and confuse their language") are also used to buttress the claim of an underlying polytheism _within_ Judaism, just as they are used by certain Christian theologians to stake an ahistorical claim to trinitarianism.

But polytheistic Judaism? "Sh'ma Yisrael Adonai Eloheinu Adonai Eḥad" I mean, can it get any clearer?

See http://maxwellinstitute.byu.edu/publications/review/?vol=19&num=1&am... for a long, critical close reading; the Hebrew text for Psamlm 82 and a literal translation is here: http://biblos.com/psalms/82-1.htm

& see Ps. 82/1: 'God stands in the divine assembly, among the divine beings he pronounces judgement....' (TANACH/Kethuvin; JPS 1999./5759); /God/ & /divine beings/ are both /elohim/, that archaic plural term. It may relate, as do many references to the /host of heaven/, to the ancient Chaldean identification of various gods with stars.

Re: the head God called together  the Gods....", it is not clear to me where this translation comes from. Also, it would be helpful to see it in the original Hebrew. While I am not a Hebrew scholar some translation difficulties are clearly apparent. First, Hebrew has no capital letters. In English I believe it is common practice to capitalize the deity in reference to the God of Abraham. Also, I believe that in English when multiple deities are referenced, we do not capitalize. However in Hebrew, both El and Elohim are used to refer to the God of Abraham even though the first is singular and the second is plural. So possibly the Hebrew text read "the head El called together the Elohim but that doesn't necessarily translate that the head God called together the Gods. BTW, I only capitalized to be consistent with the usage in the original commentary.
